huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: The moose population on this unit is stable to slightly increasing. Recent collar data suggests a healthy population with near average recruitment.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
Cellular phone coverage is spotty on this hunt unit. Satellite phones do work in the area. A "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety can be used if you decide to camp in an area without cell phone service and do not wish to travel to reach service. Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.

Camps should be kept clean to prevent bear incidents. Food should be kept inside vehicles or bear-proof containers. Coolers are not bear-proof. Bears have gotten into camps in the past in this unit. Number and severity of bear incidents differ by year depending on weather and other food availability. Meat and garbage should be put away inside a vehicle or hung in a tree above 8 feet off the ground and 3 feet away from the trunk or any branches of the tree.

Moose can be unpredictable and dangerous if you encroach into their space. Females can be protective of young and may charge if they perceive you as a threat. Males can be defensive, especially during the rut.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, snow, wind and heat.  It is quite common on clear mornings for clouds to build through the morning and have thunderstorms in the afternoon.  Be very cautious of lightning if you’re crossing high ridges or exposed slopes.  Early fall snow storms occur occasionally in this area.  Most years the snow will melt off within a day or two until through the first week of October.  Some years a big snowstorm will hit the beginning of October and make some roads impassable.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 93.8~200~200~~~3.75–4.25~6~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Location of harvest: Moose are very large animals and difficult to haul long distances. They are often found near or in water. Do not shoot if you cannot retrieve the animal where it may go down, such as in a lake or stream. Choose your shot wisely; you may have to wait for it to move to a better location.

Migration Patterns: Moose do not show a definite migration pattern on this unit.. They are not as dependent on water sources during the winter months. Snow depth also does not seem to affect where they are located.

Scouting Tips: Scouting trips are highly recommended in order to become familiar with the area. A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential. Plan to spend a lot of time hiking in areas away from human disturbance. Bull Moose can move long distances, especially during the rut when they are in search of cows so you may not see the same moose on different scouting trips.

Behavior: Like other wildlife, moose are most active in the early mornings and evenings, but they can be up and moving any time of the day. They are often found in mountain riparian areas, near lakes and streams, with willows or aspen. During the rut, bulls and cows will call to attract mates. This can be useful in finding bulls in the thick vegetation.

Moose rut: The moose rut usually runs during September and October.

Recommended areas: High elevation riparian and wet meadow habitat types, away from human disturbance.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: US Forest Service campgrounds managed by the Mtn. View-Evanston Wyoming ranger District
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: SR-150 south from Evanston, Wyo., SR-246 south from Mtn. View Wyo
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Uinta-Wasatch-Cache National Froests Salt Lake, Kamas, Evanston, Mtn. View Ranger Districts
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: See USFS motor vehicle map for the Mtn. View-Evanston Ranger District
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Summit County--Boundary begins at the Utah-Wyoming state line and SR-150; south on SR-150 to the Summit-Duchesne county line at Hayden Pass; east on this county line to the head of Burnt Fork drainage bottom(Divide Pass/Island Lake); north along this drainage bottom to the Utah-Wyoming state line; west on this state line to SR-150. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Kings Peak. Boundary questions? Call Ogden office, 801-476-2740.
